entry.title: Brussels Bound? Probing a Different Path for Armenia's Future

media:group.media:title: Brussels Bound? Probing a Different Path for Armenia's Future
media:group.media:description:
In this week's episode of Insights, host Eric Hacopian analyzes recent comments from Russian President Vladimir Putin regarding Armenia. He also discusses an open letter from Armenia's Foreign Minister to European parliament members about Yerevan's EU aspirations. Hacopian decodes the intentions and strategic signals behind these developments while reflecting on Armenia's foreign policy challenges in 2023.

entry.title: Inside Nrnadzor, Armenia‚Äôs border village struggling to survive

media:group.media:title: Inside Nrnadzor, Armenia‚Äôs border village struggling to survive
media:group.media:description:
In the remote southern reaches of the Syunik Region, the village of Nrnadzor is known for its harsh living conditions. This village is home to 141 residents, including 13 who have been displaced from Artsakh. It faces many challenges including rocky roads, and a lack of water, gas, and cable internet infrastructure. Its primary source of income comes from pomegranate orchards, however, due to insufficient irrigation, their harvests are decreasing. In this video, CivilNet speaks to the residents of Nrnadzor to understand the daily difficulties they face.

entry.title: Pashinyan rebukes Putin and calls November 9 agreement ‚Äúwatered down‚Äù

media:group.media:title: Pashinyan rebukes Putin and calls November 9 agreement ‚Äúwatered down‚Äù
media:group.media:description:
üìçPashinyan says November 9 agreement "watered down", blames Russian peacekeepers for not protecting Nagorno-Karabakh population. üìçA Russian army deserter who fled to Armenia was arrested and extradited, apparently without the permission of Armenian authorities. üìçExtravagant Christmas tree lighting in Republic Square raises questions about optics amid the loss of Nagorno-Karabakh. üìçListen to an interview with new Canadian Ambassador to Armenia Andrew Turner on the two nations‚Äô partnership and priorities. entry.title: No Mud, No Lotus: #mindfulleaders with Larisa Hovhannisyan #shorts

media:group.media:title: No Mud, No Lotus: #mindfulleaders with Larisa Hovhannisyan #shorts
media:group.media:description:
Watch full interview: https://youtu.be/yQfg2h0gYtg In this episode, we explore the life of Larisa Hovannisian, from her childhood and education in Yerevan, Moscow, Wisconsin, and Phoenix to her life as the founder and CEO of Teach for Armenia. We explore important topics such as her family roots, her journey in establishing Teach for Armenia, and the challenges and drives that helped her become a successful social entrepreneur. Finally, Larisa shares her view on the importance of faith, self-belief, life purpose, parenthood, social-emotional learning, and the role of education today.
About Larisa Hovannisian Larisa Hovannisian is the founder and CEO of Teach for Armenia, a social impact organization dedicated to catalyzing impact-driven leaders addressing educational inequity for all children in Armenia and formerly in Artsakh. She holds a double degree in International Business and French, a minor in Graphic Design from St. Norbert College in De Pere, Wisconsin, and a master‚Äôs degree in special education from Arizona State University. As an educational activist, Larisa was nationally recognized by the Armenian government in 2016 for her contribution to the advancement of Armenia through her work with Teach for Armenia.
